>>=
 better
>> coder than me :)
>
>I hope this was tongue-in-cheek. I don't thi=
nk I have *ever* 
>returned the wrong 
>variable from a getX() method[1]. I=
n order to make this 
>mistake, I'd have to be 
>drunk. As for setting the =
wrong variable in a setX() method, 
>see my previous 
>message. I've made t=
hat mistake exactly once.

That's wonderful. I have made this mistake great=
er than one times (and I wasn't drunk! :-)

>Folks, don't test the getX() a=
nd setX() methods; but rather 
>test that the 
>constructor stores the appr=
opriate parameter in the 
>appropriate field. I know 

But isn't this what =
testing the setter and getter is doing?? While I am in the minority here, I=
 am testing my accessors and I am intending to continue testing my accessor=
s. I have no desire to change your behaviour, but there are other people ou=
t there who are going to read this and ask themselves whether they are wron=
g or paranoid to be testing getters and setters. To these people, I say "Te=
st away!" I have found it useful to test everything that I can. You do not =
find it useful, so don't test what you are certain cannot break.

>I'm abou=
t 100 times more likely to write a bug there than in 
>the getX() or setX
>=
() method itself.

That's your personal situation. Some of us still make th=
at mistake.

I've been programming since I was in my early teens (1980 if I=
 remember correctly) and I still have a couple of mistakes that I make regu=
larly. My most common one is to forget to increment loop counters. Now that=
's a dumb mistake and I'm sure that I'm the only person on the list who mak=
es that mistake, but make it I do. Those endless loops always make for lots=
 of fun! :-)

>[1] Note that I'm ignoring cases where the compiler caught a=
 typo.

Not all languages that junit has been ported to will do that!

Simo=
n
